towns|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/russian-and-ukraine-troops-battle-in-south-prompting-fears-of-widescale-invasion/2014/08/28/04b614f4-9a6e-40f4-aa21-4f49104cf0e4_story.html|accessdate=30 August 2014|work=washingtonpost.com|publisher=The Washington Post|date=28 August 2014}} and Russian soldiers began arresting and deporting to unknown locations all Ukrainians who did not have an address registered within the town.{{cite web|url=http://wiadomosci.gazeta.pl/wiadomosci/1,114881,16542864,Jaceniuk__Putin_rozpoczal_wojne_w_Europie__chcemy.html?entry=1231554 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140903081128/http://wiadomosci.gazeta.pl/wiadomosci/1%2C114881%2C16542864%2CJaceniuk__Putin_rozpoczal_wojne_w_Europie__chcemy.html?entry=1231554 |archivedate= 3 September 2014 |title=NATO: 1000 rosyjskich żołnierzy działa na Ukrainie. A Rosja znów: Nie przekraczaliśmy granicy [NA ŻYWO] |website=gazeta.pl |date=28 August 2014 |accessdate=14 October 2014 |language=pl |deadurl=yes |df= }} Pro-Ukrainian anti-war protests took place in [[Mariupol]] which was threatened by Russian troops.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-28963310|title=BBC:Ukraine crisis: 'Thousands of Russians' fighting in east, August 28|work=BBC News|accessdate=14 October 2014}} The [[UN Security Council]] called an emergency meeting to discuss the situation. On 3 September, a [[Sky News]] team filmed groups of troops near [[Novoazovsk]] wearing modern combat gear typical for Russian units and traveling in new military vehicles with number plates and other markings removed. Specialists consulted by the journalists identified parts of the equipment (uniform, rifles) as currently used by Russian ground forces and paratroopers.{{cite web | url=https://news.sky.com/story/sky-films-troops-in-russian-gear-in-ukraine-10390971 | title=Sky Films Troops 'In Russian Gear' In Ukraine | publisher=Sky News | date=3 September 2014 | accessdate=4 September 2014}} ====Result==== On 3 September, Ukrainian President Poroshenko said he had reached a permanent ceasefire agreement with Russian President Putin.{{cite news|url=http://www.interfax.ru/world/394762|title=В Кремле и Киеве разъяснили заявление о прекращении огня в Донбассе|agency=Interfax|accessdate=14 September 2014|language=ru}} Russia then denied the ceasefire took place, denying being party to the conflict at all.{{cite web|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/poroshenko-and-putin-agree-on-ceasefire-363171.html|title=Kremlin denies that Poroshenko and Putin agreed on ceasefire (UPDATES)|publisher=kyivpost.com|accessdate=14 September 2014}} Ukraine then retracted its previous statement concerning the potential ceasefire.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/04/world/europe/ukraine-russia.html?emc=edit_na_20140903&_r=0|title=Putin Lays Out Proposal to End Ukraine Conflict|work=nytimes.com|author=Neil MacFarquhar|date=3 September 2014|accessdate=15 February 2015}} Also on 3 September, the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] for the first time reported "light and heavy calibre shootings from the east and south-east areas which are also bordering Ukraine". The report also stated that the OSCE Observer Teams had seen an increase of military-style dressed men crossing the border in both directions, including ones with LPR and Novorossiya symbols and flags, and wounded being transported back to Russia.{{cite web | url=http://www.osce.org/om/123151 | title=Weekly update from the OSCE Observer Mission at the Russian Checkpoints Gukovo and Donetsk, 28 August until 08:00, 3 September 2014 | publisher=OSCE | date=3 September 2014 | accessdate=4 September 2014}} ====Reaction==== [[Lindsey Hilsum]] wrote in the [[Channel 4]] news blog that in early September Ukrainian troops at [[Dmytrivka, Donetsk Oblast|Dmytrivka]] came under attack from [[BM-30 Smerch]] rockets from Russia.{{cite news|last1=Hilsum|first1=Lindsay|title='Tell them please don't think that Putin will stop at Ukraine'|url=http://blogs.channel4.com/lindsey-hilsum-on-international-affairs/tell-putin-stop-ukraine/4411|accessdate=26 September 2014|work=Newsblog|publisher=Channel 4 News}} On 4 September, she wrote of rumours that Ukrainian troops who had been shelling Luhansk for weeks were retreating west and that Russian soldiers with heavy armour were reported to have come over the border to back up the rebels.{{cite news|author=Lindsey Hilsum|title=Pride and despair along the country roads of Ukraine|url=http://blogs.channel4.com/lindsey-hilsum-on-international-affairs/ukraine-journey/4377#sthash.uDkFx3qs.dpuf|publisher=Channel 4|date=4 September 2014|accessdate=26 September 2014}} Journalist [[Tim Judah]] wrote in the [[The New York Review of Books|NYR]] blog about the scale of the devastation suffered by Ukrainian forces in southeastern Ukraine over the last week of August 2014 that it amounted "to a catastrophic defeat and will long be remembered by embittered Ukrainians as among the darkest days of their history." The scale of the destruction achieved in several ambushes revealed "that those attacking the pro-government forces were highly professional and using very powerful weapons." The fighting in Ilovaysk had begun on 7 August when units from three Ukrainian volunteer militias and the police attempted to take it back from rebel control. Then, on 28 August, the rebels were able to launch a major offensive, with help from elsewhere, including Donetsk—though "not Russia," according to Commander Givi, the head of rebel forces there. By 1 September it was all over and the Ukrainians had been decisively defeated. Commander Givi said the ambushed forces were militias, not regular soldiers, whose numbers had been boosted, 'by foreigners, including Czechs, Hungarians, and "niggers." '{{cite web|url=http://www.nybooks.com/blogs/nyrblog/2014/sep/05/ukraine-catastrophic-defeat/|title=Ukraine: A Catastrophic Defeat by Tim Judah|work=nybooks.com|accessdate= 11 April 2015}} [[Mick Krever]] wrote on the [[CNN]] blog that on 5 September Russia's Permanent Representative to the OSCE, Andrey Kelin had said it was natural pro-Russian separatists "are going to liberate" [[Mariupol]]. Ukrainian forces stated that Russian intelligence groups had been spotted in the area. Kelin said 'there might be volunteers over there.'{{cite news|url=http://amanpour.blogs.cnn.com/2014/09/05/russian-ambassador-anticipates-liberation-of-mariupol-in-ukraine/|title=Russian ambassador anticipates 'liberation' of Mariupol in Ukraine|work=cnn.com|accessdate= 11 April 2015|date=5 September 2014}} NATO Secretary General Anders Fogh Rasmussen meanwhile said there were several thousand regular Russian forces operating in Ukraine.{{citation needed|date=October 2014}} [[Lindsey Hilsum]] reported on the [[Channel 4]] news blog about the total destruction of [[Luhansk International Airport]] which was being used as a base by the Ukrainian forces to shell Luhansk, probably because the Russians decided to 'turn the tide' - the terminal building and everything around was utterly destroyed. Forces from Azerbaijan, Belarus and Tajikistan who were fighting on the side of the rebels allowed themselves to be filmed.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.channel4.com/lindsey-hilsum-on-international-affairs/shards-rubble-luhansk-airport/4419|title=Lindsey Hilsum, Channel 4 report, 6 September 2014|publisher=|accessdate=14 October 2014}} On 12 September 2014, the ''Guardian'' saw a Russian armoured personnel carrier in [[Lutuhyne]].{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/sep/12/armoured-russian-vehicle-inside-ukraine |title= Armoured Russian vehicle seen inside Ukraine |first= Shaun |last= Walker |work= The Guardian |date= 12 September 2014 |accessdate= 11 April 2015}} The next day, it was reported that Moscow had sent a convoy of trucks delivering "aid" into Ukraine without Kiev's consent. This convoy was not inspected by Ukraine or accompanied by the ICRC. Top Ukrainian leaders largely remained silent about the convoys after the ceasefire deal was reached. The "aid" was part of the 12-point [[Minsk agreement]].{{cite web|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/ukraine-pm-says-country-still-state-war|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140913192133/http://bigstory.ap.org/article/ukraine-pm-says-country-still-state-war|archivedate=13 September 2014|title=Ukraine government repels rebel attack on airport|work=The Big Story}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/sep/13/vladimir-putin-wants-destroy-ukraine-says-arseny-yetseniuk|title=Ukraine fights off attack on Donetsk airport by pro-Russia forces|author=Martin Williams|work=the Guardian}} The [[Valentina Matviyenko|speaker of Russia's upper house of parliament]] and Russian state television channels acknowledged that Russian soldiers entered Ukraine, but referred to them as "volunteers".{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-29078465|agency=BBC News|title=Russia 'will react' to EU sanctions|first=Martin|last=Morgan|date=5 September 2014|accessdate=6 September 2014}} A reporter for ''[[Novaya Gazeta]]'', an opposition newspaper in Russia, stated that the Russian military leadership paid soldiers to resign their commissions and fight in Ukraine in the early summer of 2014, and then began ordering soldiers into Ukraine. This reporter mentioned knowledge of at least one case when soldiers who refused were threatened with prosecution.{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/09/06/elena-racheva_n_5774138.html|agency=The Huffington Post|title=Russian Journalist: 'Convincing Evidence' Moscow Sent Fighters To Ukraine|first=Charlotte|last=Alfred|date=6 September 2014|accessdate=6 September 2014}} Russian opposition MP [[Lev Shlosberg]] made similar statements, although he said combatants from his country are "regular Russian troops", disguised as units of the DPR and LPR.{{cite news|url=http://www.dw.de/disowned-and-forgotten-russian-soldiers-in-ukraine/a-17888902|agency=Deutsche Welle|title=Disowned and forgotten: Russian soldiers in Ukraine|date=29 August 2014|accessdate=6 September 2014|first=Alexander|last=Warketin}} In December, Ukrainian hackers published a large cache of documents coming allegedly from a hacked server of Russian Ministry of Internal Affairs (MID). The documents originated from various departments coordinated by MID, such as local police, road police, emergency services etc. The cache included documents describing Russian military casualties arriving on 25 August to hospitals in the Rostov area after a battle "10 km northwest of the small village of Prognoi", which matched a battle in Krasnaya Talovka reported on the same date by Ukrainian side.{{cite web | url=http://globalvoicesonline.org/2014/12/13/ukrainian-hackers-leak-russian-interior-ministry-docs-with-evidence-of-russian-invasion/ | title=Ukrainian Hackers Leak Russian Interior Ministry Docs with 'Evidence' of Russian Invasion | publisher=Global Voices Online | date=13 December 2014 | accessdate=13 December 2014 | author=Aric Toler}} In early September 2014, Russian state-owned television channels reported on the funerals of Russian soldiers who died in Ukraine during the [[war in Donbass]], but described them as "volunteers" fighting for the "[[Russian world]]". [[Valentina Matviyenko]], a top politician in the ruling [[United Russia]] party, also praised "volunteers" fighting in "our fraternal nation", referring to Ukraine. Russian state television for the first time showed the funeral of a soldier killed fighting in east Ukraine. State-controlled TV station Channel One showed the burial of paratrooper Anatoly Travkin in the central Russian city of [[Kostroma]]. The broadcaster said Travkin had not told his wife or commanders about his decision to fight alongside pro-Russia rebels battling government forces. "Officially he just went on leave," the news reader said.The Guardian, 5 September 2014{{Verify source|date=August 2016}} After a series of military defeats and setbacks for the Donetsk and Lugansk separatists, who united under the [[flag of the Federal State of Novorossiya|banner]] of "[[Federal State of Novorossiya|Novorossiya]]", a term Russian President [[Vladimir Putin]] used to describe southeastern Ukraine,{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/04/18/putin-novorossiya-ukraine_n_5173559.html|work=The Huffington Post|title=Here's Why Putin Calling Eastern Ukraine 'Novorossiya' Is Important|date=18 April 2014|accessdate=28 August 2014}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/18/world/europe/russia-ukraine.html?_r=0|work=The New York Times|title=Away From Show of Diplomacy in Geneva, Putin Puts on a Show of His Own|date=17 April 2014|accessdate=28 August 2014|first=David M.|last=Herszenhorn}} Russia dispatched what it called a "humanitarian convoy" of trucks across the [[Russo-Ukrainian border]] in mid-August 2014. Ukraine reacted to the move by calling it a "direct invasion".{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/22/russian-convoy-crosses-border-ukraine-without-permission|work=The Guardian|title=Ukraine condemns 'direct invasion' as Russian aid convoy crosses border|date=22 August 2014|accessdate=28 August 2014}} Ukraine's National Security and Defense Council published a report on the number and contents of these convoys, claiming they were arriving almost daily in November (up to 9 convoys on 30 November) and their contents were mainly arms and ammunition. In total, in November there were 1,903 trucks crossing the border from Russia to Donbass, 20 buses with soldiers or volunteers, 402 armoured personnel carriers, 256 tanks, 138 "Grad" launchers, 42 cannons and howitzers, 35 self-propelled artillery vehicles, 5 "Buk" launchers, 4 "Uragan" launchers, 4 "Buratino" flamethrowers, 6 pontoon bridge trucks, 5 "Taran" radio interception systems, 5 armoured recovery vehicles, 3 radiolocation systems, 2 truck cranes, 1 track layer vehicle, 1 radiolocation station, unknown number of "Rtut-BM" electronic warfare systems, 242 fuel tankers and 205 light off-road vehicles and vans.{{cite web | url=http://atocrimea.ukrinform.ua/en/publication/the-real-convoys-behind-white-trucks | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141227144621/http://atocrimea.ukrinform.ua/en/publication/the-real-convoys-behind-white-trucks | archivedate=27 December 2014 | title=The real convoys behind white trucks | publisher=National Security and Defense Council of Ukraine | date=December 2014 | accessdate=27 December 2014}} About the same time, multiple reports indicated separatist militias were receiving reinforcements that allowed them to turn the tables on government forces.{{cite news|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/08/16/ukraine-rebels-boast-about-troops-and-tanks-coming-from-russia.html|agency=The Daily Beast|title=Ukraine Rebels Boast About Troops and Tanks Coming from Russia|date=16 August 2014|accessdate=28 August 2014}} Armoured columns coming from Russia also pushed into southern Donetsk Oblast and reportedly captured the town of [[Novoazovsk]], clashing with Ukrainian forces and opening a new front in the Donbass conflict.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-28924945 |title= Ukraine crisis: 'Column from Russia' crosses border |publisher=BBC|date=|accessdate=26 August 2014}}{{cite news | url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2014/08/26/uk-ukraine-crisis-novoazovsk-idUKKBN0GQ19Y20140826 | title=In Ukraine, an armoured column appears out of nowhere | agency=Reuters | date=26 August 2014 | accessdate=26 August 2014}} Russian officials denied{{cite news|title=Russia denies reports of military presence in Ukraine|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/08/28/us-ukraine-crisis-denial-idUSKBN0GS22Z20140828|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=10 September 2014|first=Mark|last=Trevelyan|date=28 August 2014}} reports that Russian military units were operating in Ukraine (see [[War in Donbass]]), claiming instead they had been sent on routine drills close to the border with Ukraine{{cite web|title=Russian TV shows funeral of soldier killed 'on leave' in Ukraine|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/sep/05/russia-tv-funeral-soldier-killed-ukraine-on-leave|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=10 September 2014}} and crossed the border by mistake.{{cite news|title=Ukraine crisis: Russian soldiers captured in conflict area crossed border 'by accident'|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/ukraine-crisis-russian-paratroopers-captured-in-conflict-area-crossed-border-by-accident-9690752.html|publisher=The Independent|accessdate=10 September 2014|location=London|first=Heather|last=Saul|date=26 August 2014}} On 28 August 2014 Dutch Brigadier-General Nico Tak, head of NATO's crisis management center, said that "over 1,000 Russian troops are now operating inside Ukraine".{{cite news|author=Adrian Croft|title=More than 1,000 Russian troops operating in Ukraine: NATO|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/08/28/us-ukraine-crisis-nato-idUSKBN0GS1D220140828|publisher=Reuters|date=28 August 2014|accessdate=10 September 2014}} On 5 September, Sergey Krivenko, a member of Russian President's Council for Civil Society and Human Rights, commented on the growing number of Russian soldiers killed in Ukraine, saying that "the situation now is very strange, something unusual is going on; it could be described as massive dying of soldiers, which is not typical for a time of peace; people from different military units are killed as a result of shots, from loss of blood, all these reasons are documented; and the military command explains that it happened during training or provides no explanation at all".{{cite web | url=http://7x7-journal.ru/item/46836 | title=Член Совета по правам человека при Президенте России Сергей Кривенко | publisher=7x7 | date=5 September 2014 | accessdate=11 September 2014 |trans-title=(Interview with) Member of Council for Civil Society and Human Rights Sergey Krivenko}}{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2014/08/28/uk-ukraine-crisis-russia-casualties-idUKKBN0GS20H20140828|title=Exclusive - Over 100 Russian soldiers killed in single Ukraine battle - Russian rights activists|work=reuters.com | date=28 August 2014}} ===November 2014 escalation=== On 7 November, NATO officials confirmed the continued invasion of Ukraine, with 32 Russian tanks, 16 howitzer cannons and 30 trucks of troops entering the country.{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/story/1368812/russia-sends-dozens-of-tanks-into-ukraine|title=Russia Sends Dozens Of Tanks Into Ukraine|work=Sky News|date=7 November 2014|accessdate=8 November 2014}} On 12 November, NATO reiterated the prevalence of Russian troops; US general Philip Breedlove said "Russian tanks, Russian artillery, Russian air defence systems and Russian combat troops" were sighted. The Lithuanian Mission to the United Nations denounced Russia's 'undeclared war' on Ukraine.{{cite web|url=http://un.mfa.lt/index.php?1440223596|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141113031148/http://un.mfa.lt/index.php?1440223596|archivedate=13 November 2014|title=Lithuania's statement at the UN Security Council briefing on Ukraine|work=Permanent Mission of the Republic of Lithuania to UN in New York|date=13 November 2014|accessdate=21 November 2013}} Journalist Menahem Kahana took a picture showing a 1RL232 "Leopard" battlefield surveillance radar system in Torez, east of Donetsk; and Dutch freelance journalist Stefan Huijboom took pictures which showed the 1RL232 traveling with the 1RL239 "Lynx" radar system.{{cite web|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/articles/2014/11/13/russian_tanks_ukraine_battlefield_radar_reinforcements_putin_donetsk|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141114002023/http://www.foreignpolicy.com/articles/2014/11/13/russian_tanks_ukraine_battlefield_radar_reinforcements_putin_donetsk|archivedate=14 November 2014|title=Putin Sends His 'Leopard' to the Battlefield of Eastern Ukraine|work=Foreign Policy}} Burnt-out remains of tanks and vehicles left after battles appeared to provide further evidence of Russian involvement.{{cite web|url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/journalists-find-mounting-evidence-of-russian-involvement-in-ukraine/509973.html|title=Journalists Find Mounting Evidence of Russian Involvement in Ukraine |work=The Moscow Times|accessdate= 11 April 2015}} The Associated Press reported 80 unmarked military vehicles on the move in rebel-controlled areas. Three separate columns were observed, one near the main separatist stronghold of Donetsk and two outside the town of [[Snizhne]]. Several of the trucks were seen to be carrying troops. OSCE monitors further observed vehicles apparently used to transport soldiers' dead bodies crossing the Russian-Ukrainian border{{snd}} in one case a vehicle marked with [[Cargo 200 (code name)|Russia's military code for soldiers killed in action]] crossed from Russia into Ukraine on 11 November 2014 and later returned. On 23 January 2015 the Committee of Soldiers' Mothers warned about conscripts being sent to east Ukraine.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/11365982/Ukraine-Separatist-forces-in-Donetsk-cannot-maintain-offensive-without-Russian-support.html|title=Ukraine: Separatist forces in Donetsk cannot maintain offensive without Russian support|date=23 January 2015 |accessdate=11 April 2015|work=Telegraph|location=London|first=Roland|last=Oliphant}} NATO said it had seen an increase in Russian tanks, artillery pieces and other heavy military equipment in eastern Ukraine and renewed its call for Moscow to withdraw its forces.{{cite news|url=http://uatoday.tv/geopolitics/nato-sees-increase-of-russian-tanks-and-artillery-in-ukraine-404317.html|title=NATO sees increase of Russian tanks and artillery in Ukraine|agency=Ukraine Today|date=22 January 2015|accessdate=11 August 2016}} The Center for Eurasian Strategic Intelligence estimated, based on "official statements and interrogation records of captured military men from these units, satellite surveillance data" as well as verified announcements from relatives and profiles in social networks, that over 30 Russian military units were taking part in the conflict in Ukraine. In total, over 8,000 soldiers had fought there at different moments.{{cite web |url=http://eurasianintelligence.org/news.php?new=108&num |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141016232436/http://eurasianintelligence.org/news.php?new=108&num |archivedate=16 October 2014 |title=Russian units participating in combat actions in Ukraine |publisher=Center for Eurasian Strategic Intelligence |date=22 October 2014 |accessdate=22 October 2014}} The [[Chicago Council on Global Affairs]] stated that the Russian separatists enjoyed technical advantages over the Ukrainian army since the large inflow of advanced military systems in mid-2014: effective anti-aircraft weapons ("Buk", MANPADS) suppressed Ukrainian air strikes, Russian drones provided intelligence, and Russian secure communications system thwarted the Ukrainian side from communications intelligence. The Russian side also frequently employed electronic warfare systems that Ukraine lacked. Similar conclusions about the technical advantage of the Russian separatists were voiced by the Conflict Studies Research Centre.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-31146595 |title=Ukraine crisis: Russia tests new weapons |publisher=BBC |date=6 February 2015 |accessdate=7 February 2015 |first=Keir|last=Giles}} In November 2014, [[Igor Girkin]] gave a long interview to the extreme right-wing{{cite web|url=https://www.academia.edu/4348334/Russia_-_The_Uses_of_Extremism_The_Emergence_of_Three_Far-Right_Discussion_Clubs_and_Their_Links_to_the_Kremlin_Spell_More_Bad_News_for_East-West_Relations|title=Russia — The Uses of Extremism: The Emergence of Three Far-Right Discussion Clubs and Their Links to the Kremlin Spell More Bad News for East-West Relations|first=Andreas|last=Umland|publisher=|accessdate= 11 April 2015}} nationalist newspaper ''Zavtra'' ("Tomorrow") where for the first time he released details about the beginning of the conflict in Donbass. According to Girkin, he was the one who "pulled the trigger of war" and it was necessary because acquisition of Crimea alone by Russia "did not make sense" and Crimea as part of the Novorossiya "would make the jewel in the crown of the [[Russian Empire]]". Girkin had been directed to Donbass by [[Sergey Aksyonov]] and he entered Ukraine with a group of 52 officers in April, initially taking Slavyansk, Kramatorsk and then other cities. Girkin also talked about the situation in August, when separatist forces were close to defeat and only a prompt intervention of Russian "leavers" (ironic term for "soldiers on leave") saved them. Their forces took command in the siege of Mariupol as well.{{cite web |url=http://zavtra.ru/content/view/kto-tyi-strelok/ |script-title=ru:"Кто ты, "Стрелок"?" |work=Zavtra |date=20 November 2014 |accessdate=20 November 2014 |first1=Alexander|last1=Prokhanov|authorlink1=Alexander Prokhanov |first2=Igor|last2=Strelkov |trans-title=Who are you, Strelok? |language=ru}}{{cite web |url=http://uatoday.tv/politics/former-insurgent-chief-s-claim-punctures-kremlin-denials-392885.html |title='We started Ukraine war', confesses insurgent leader Girkin |publisher=Ukraine Today |date=20 November 2014 |accessdate=21 November 2014}} In response to internal criticism of the Russian government's policy of not officially recognizing Russian soldiers in Ukraine as fulfilling military service and leaving their families without any source of income if they are killed, president Vladimir Putin signed a new law in October entitling their families to a monthly compensation. Two new entitlement categories were added: "missing in action" and "declared dead" (as of 1 January 2016).{{cite web |url=http://www.interpretermag.com/russia-this-week-putins-neo-imperialism-and-the-price-of-oil/ |title=Russia This Week: Kremlin Announces Compensation for Missing and Killed Servicemen |work=The Interpreter Magazine |date=24 October 2014 |accessdate=24 October 2014 |first=Catherine A.|last=Fitzpatrick}}{{cite web |url=http://kremlin.ru/acts/news/46843 |title=Внесены изменения в закон о денежном довольствии военнослужащих |website=kremlin.ru|publisher=Executive Office of the President of the Russian Federation|date=23 October 2014 |accessdate=24 October 2014|language=ru}} Alexandr Negrebetskih, a deputy from the Russian city of [[Zlatoust]] who fought as a volunteer on the side of separatists, complained in an interview that "the locals run to Russia, and we have to come here as they are reluctant to defend their land" which resulted in his detachment being composed of 90% Russians and only 10% locals from [[Donetsk]].{{cite web |url=http://ura.ru/articles/1036263086 |title=Из-за неграмотного командования нас расстреливают в упор! |publisher=URA.ru |date=3 October 2014 |accessdate=3 October 2014 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6T3JI3G0t?url=http://ura.ru/content/chel/01-10-2014/articles/1036263086.html |archivedate=3 October 2014 |trans-title=Because of poor command we are being killed! |language=ru |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all}} In November, Lev Shlosberg published a response from a military attorney's office to questions he asked about the status of Pskov paratroopers killed in Ukraine in August. The office answered that the soldiers died while "fulfilling military service outside of their permanent dislocation units" (Pskov), but any further information on their orders or location of death was withheld as "classified". A political expert Alexey Makarkin compared these answers to those provided by Soviet ministry of defence during the [[Soviet–Afghan War]] when the [[USSR]] attempted to hide the scale of their casualties at any cost.{{cite web |url=http://www.gazeta.ru/social/2014/11/10/6297181.shtml |script-title=ru:Гостайна о гибели псковских десантников |publisher=Gazeta.ru |date=11 November 2014 |accessdate=11 November 2014 |trans-title=Classified response on death of Pskov paratroopers |language=ru}} Numerous reports of Russian troops and warfare on Ukrainian territory were raised in [[United Nations Security Council]] meetings. In 12 November meeting, the representative of the United Kingdom also accused Russia of intentionally constraining [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] observatory missions' capabilities, pointing out that the observers were allowed to monitor only two kilometers of border between Ukraine and Russia, and drones deployed to extend their capabilities were being jammed or shot down.{{cite web |url=http://webtv.un.org/meetings-events/security-council/watch/ukraine-security-council-7311th-meeting/3888744131001 |title=Ukraine — Security Council, 7311th meeting |publisher=United Nations |date=12 November 2014 |accessdate=13 November 2014}} In November, Armament Research Services published a detailed report on arms used by both sides of the conflict, documenting a number of "flag items". Among vehicles, they documented the presence of T-72B Model 1989 and T-72B3 tanks, armoured vehicles of models BTR-82AM, MT-LB 6MA, MT-LBVM, and MT-LBVMK, and an Orlan-10 drone and 1RL239 radar vehicle. Among the ammunition, they documented [[9K38 Igla]] (date of manufacture 2014), ASVK rifle (2012), RPG-18 rocket launchers (2011), 95Ya6 rocket boosters (2009) MRO-A (2008), [[9M133 Kornet]] anti-tank weapons (2007), PPZR Grom (2007), MON-50 (2002), RPO-A (2002), PKP (2001), OG-7 (2001), and VSS rifles (1987). These weapons, mostly manufactured in Russia, were used by pro-Russian separatists in the conflict zone, but never "were in the Ukrainian government inventory prior to the outbreak of hostilities". The report also noted the use of PPZR Grom [[MANPAD]]s, produced in Poland and never exported to Ukraine. They were however exported to Georgia in 2007 and subsequently captured by the Russian army during the [[Russian-Georgian War 2008]].{{cite web|url=http://armamentresearch.com/Uploads/Research%20Report%20No.%203%20-%20Raising%20Red%20Flags.pdf|title=Raising Red Flags: An Examination of Arms & Munitions in the Ongoing Conflict in Ukraine|format=PDF|publisher=Armaments Research Services|date=2012|accessdate=20 November 2014}} Also in November, [[Pantsir-S1]] units were observed in separatist-controlled areas near [[Novoazovsk]], which were never part of the UAF's inventory.{{cite web|last=Nemtsova|first=Anna |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/11/10/in-ukraine-winter-is-coming-and-so-are-the-russians.html |title=Ukraine Could Explode in the Next 48 Hours |work=The Daily Beast |date=10 November 2014 |accessdate=5 February 2015}} [[Bellingcat]] maintains a dedicated database of geolocated images of military vehicles specific to each side of the conflict, mostly focused on Russian military equipment found on Ukrainian territory.{{cite web |url=http://bellingcat-vehicles.silk.co/ |title=Bellingcat Vehicles |publisher=Bellingcat |accessdate=13 February 2015}} ===2015=== In January 2015, an image of a [[BPM-97]] apparently inside Ukraine, in [[Luhansk]], provided further evidence of Russian military vehicles inside Ukraine.{{cite web |url=https://www.bellingcat.com/news/uk-and-europe/2015/01/03/did-russia-send-a-new-batch-of-military-vehicles-to-separatists-controlled-ukraine/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150413085542/https://www.bellingcat.com/news/uk-and-europe/2015/01/03/did-russia-send-a-new-batch-of-military-vehicles-to-separatists-controlled-ukraine/ |archivedate=13 April 2015 |title=Did Russia Send a New Batch of Military Vehicles to Separatists Controlled Ukraine? |work=Bellingcat |first=Eliot |last=Higgins |date=3 January 2015 |accessdate=18 June 2015 |deadurl=no}}{{cite web |url=http://lugansk-news.com/russian-army-units-in-krasnodon-blocked-the-base-of-local-terrorists-at-least-4-russian-bpm-97-vystrel-in-the-video/ |title=Russian Army units in Krasnodon blocked the base of local terrorists. At least 4 Russian BPM-97 "Vystrel" in the video |work=Lugansk News Today |date=10 January 2015 |accessdate=18 June 2015}} [[Poroshenko]] spoke of a dangerous escalation on 21 January amid reports of more than 2,000 additional Russian troops crossing the border, together with 200 tanks and armed personnel carriers. He abbreviated his visit to the [[World Economic Forum]] in [[Davos]] because of his concerns at the worsening situation.{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-01-21/ukraine-s-poroshenko-sees-grave-danger-of-escalating-violence|title=Ukraine Talks Start as Poroshenko Warns of an Escalation|author=Francine Lacqua|work=Bloomberg.com|accessdate= 11 April 2015|date=21 January 2015}} In January, [[Donetsk]], [[Lugansk]], and [[Mariupol]] were the three cities that represented the three fronts on which Ukraine was pressed by forces armed, trained and backed by Russia.{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/01/26/ukraine-is-losing-the-war-on-3-fronts.html|title=Putin Is Winning the Ukraine War on Three Fronts|work=The Daily Beast|accessdate= 11 April 2015}} On 29 January, the chief of Ukraine's General Military Staff [[Viktor Muzhenko]] said 'the Ukrainian army is not engaged in combat operations against Russian regular units,' but that he had information about Russian civilian and military individuals fighting alongside 'illegal armed groups in combat activities.'{{citation needed|date=July 2015}}{{cite news|title=Ukraine has evidence of Russian military presence in Donbas|url=http://www.ukrinform.ua/eng/news/ukraine_has_evidence_of_russian_military_presence_in_donbas_328608|agency=Ukrinform|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150725081808/http://www.ukrinform.ua/eng/news/ukraine_has_evidence_of_russian_military_presence_in_donbas_328608|archivedate=25 July 2015}} Reporting from DPR-controlled areas on 28 January, the OSCE observed on the outskirts of [[Khartsyzk]], east of Donetsk, "a column of five T-72 tanks facing east, and immediately after, another column of four T-72 tanks moving east on the same road which was accompanied by four unmarked military trucks, type URAL. All vehicles and tanks were unmarked." It reported on an intensified movement of unmarked military trucks, covered with canvas.{{cite web|url=http://www.osce.org/ukraine-smm/137746|title=Latest from OSCE Special Monitoring Mission (SMM) to Ukraine based on information received as of 18:00 (Kyiv time), 28 January 2015|work=osce.org|accessdate= 11 April 2015}} After the shelling of residential areas in [[Offensive on Mariupol (January 2015)|Mariupol]], NATO's [[Jens Stoltenberg]] said: "Russian troops in eastern Ukraine are supporting these offensive operations with command and control systems, air defence systems with advanced surface-to-air missiles, unmanned aerial systems, advanced multiple rocket launcher systems, and electronic warfare systems."'{{cite web|url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/opinion/article/russia-is-denying-the-obvious-in-ukraine/515039.html|title=Russia Is Denying the Obvious in Ukraine - Opinion|work=The Moscow Times|accessdate= 11 April 2015}} Svetlana Davydova, a mother of seven, was accused of treason for calling the Ukrainian embassy about Russian troop movements and arrested on 27 January 2015. She was held at the high-security [[Lefortovo jail]] in Moscow until her release on 3 February with charges against her still pending. The Russian General Staff said details of the case constituted a "state secret."{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/russian-mother-seven-accused-treason-over-ukraine-224123809.html|title=Russian mother of seven accused of treason over Ukraine|date=29 January 2015|work=Yahoo News|author=Anna Smolchenko|accessdate=15 February 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://www.charlotteobserver.com/2015/02/03/5490441/husband-of-russian-treason-suspect.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150216003135/http://www.charlotteobserver.com/2015/02/03/5490441/husband-of-russian-treason-suspect.html|archivedate=16 February 2015|title=Russian mother of 7 suspected of treason released|work=charlotteobserver.com|agency=Associated Press|author=Nataliya Vasilyev|author2=Vladimir Isachenkov|date=3 February 2015|accessdate=15 February 2015}} In 2015, president Putin awarded the honorary name of "[[Guards unit|Guards]]" to two divisions: 11. paratroopers brigade from [[Ulan-Ude]], 83. paratroopers brigade from [[Ussuriysk]] and 38. communications regiment from Moscow area. The status was awarded for undisclosed combat operations.{{cite web |url=https://meduza.io/news/2015/03/25/putin-sdelal-gvardeyskimi-dve-desantnye-brigady-za-geroizm-v-boevyh-deystviyah|script-title=ru:Путин сделал гвардейскими две десантные бригады за героизм в боевых действиях|trans-title=Putin awarded guardian status to two paratrooper brigades for heroism in combat operations|language=ru|publisher=meduza.io|date=26 March 2015|accessdate=26 March 2015}} Both Ukrainian and [[Donetsk People's Republic|DNR]] sides have reported unknown sabotage groups firing at both sides of the conflict and also on residential areas, calling them a "third force".{{cite web | url=http://divannaya-sotnya.com.ua/Oblomov/pervaya-sovmestnaya-operaciya-vsu-i-dnr-po-unichtozheniyu-rossiyskih-okupantov.html | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150208114434/http://divannaya-sotnya.com.ua/Oblomov/pervaya-sovmestnaya-operaciya-vsu-i-dnr-po-unichtozheniyu-rossiyskih-okupantov.html | dead-url=yes | archive-date=8 February 2015 | title=Первая совместная операция ВСУ и ДНР по уничтожению российских окупантов | publisher=Divannaya Sotnya | date=7 February 2015 | accessdate=8 February 2015 | trans-title=First joint action of UAF and DNR destroying Russian occupiers }} [[Security Service of Ukraine|SBU]] published an intercepted call in which DNR commanders reported such a group had been arrested with Russian passports and military documents.{{cite web | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IQrrY9OwiEU | title=Російська ДРГ у Донецьку | publisher=Security Service of Ukraine | date=7 February 2015 | accessdate=8 February 2015 |trans-title=Russian sabotage group in Donetsk}} DNR confirmed that such groups were indeed stopped and "destroyed" but called them "Ukrainian sabotage groups working to discredit the armed forces of the Russian Federation".{{cite web | url=http://www.novayagazeta.ru/news/1691476.html | title=В ДНР назвали "диверсантами" воюющих в Донбассе людей в российской форме | work=Novaya Gazeta | date=8 February 2015 | accessdate=8 February 2015 |trans-title=DNR identifies fighters in Russian uniform in Donbass as "saboteurs"|language=ru}} According to a top U.S. general, Russian supplied drones and electronic [[Radar jamming and deception|jamming]] have ensured Ukrainian troops struggle to counter artillery fire by pro-Russian militants. "The rebels have Russian-provided [[UAV]]s (unmanned aerial vehicles) that are giving the rebels the detection capability and the ability to target Ukrainian forces".AFP, globalpost.com [http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/afp/150130/ukrainian-forces-face-drones-electronic-jamming Ukrainian forces face drones electronic jamming] Advanced electronic jamming was also reported by [[OSCE]] observers on numerous occasions.{{cite web|title = Latest from OSCE Special Monitoring Mission (SMM) to Ukraine based on information received as of 19:30 (Kyiv time), 19 June 2015 - OSCE|url = http://www.osce.org/ukraine-smm/165476|website = www.osce.org|accessdate = 21 June 2015}} US Army commander in Europe Ben Hodges stated in February 2015 that "it's very obvious from the amount of ammunition, type of equipment, there's direct Russian military intervention in the Debaltseve area".{{cite web | url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/russian-troops-fighting-on-ukraines-front-lines-2015-2?r=US | title=US Army commander for Europe: Russian troops are currently fighting on Ukraine's front lines | publisher=Business Insider | date=11 February 2015 | accessdate=11 February 2015}} On 9 February 2015, a group of twenty contract soldiers from [[Murmansk]] raised an official complaint to the Russian ministry of defence when they were told they would "go to the Rostov area and possibly cross the Ukrainian border to fulfill their patriotic duty". The soldiers notified human rights activists and requested the orders in written form, which they were not given.{{cite web | url=http://en.censor.net.ua/news/324659/murmansk_contract_soldiers_do_not_want_to_fight_in_ukraine_but_will_do_if_ordered | title=Murmansk contract soldiers do not want to fight in Ukraine but will do if ordered | publisher=Censor.net.ua | date=14 February 2015 | accessdate=16 February 2015}}{{cite web | url=http://tvrain.ru/articles/spch_poprosil_minoborony_proverit_zhaloby_kontraktnikov_na_ustnyj_prikaz_o_komandirovke_k_ukrainskoj_granitse-381929/ | title=СПЧ: мурманские контрактники пожаловались на принуждение ехать в Украину | publisher=TV Rain | language=ru|date=13 February 2015 | accessdate=13 February 2015}} On 13 February, a young soldier, Ilya Kudryavtsev, was found dead after calling home and informing his relatives that he was to be sent on a mission to Rostov-on-Don, which is the usual starting point to Ukraine. Although he was severely beaten, his death was officially classified as a suicide.{{cite web | url=http://www.novayagazeta.ru/news/1691712.html | title=Прокуратура начала проверку по факту смерти контрактника, рассказавшего о командировке в Ростов |trans-title=Prosecution starts an inspection after death of a soldier who said about his mission to Rostov | work=Novaya Gazeta | date=16 February 2015 | accessdate=18 February 2015|language=ru}} According to estimates by the Chicago Council on Global Affairs, Russian separatists forces number around 36,000 troops (as compared to 34,000 Ukrainian), of which 8,500-10,000 are purely Russian soldiers. Additionally, around 1,000 [[GRU]] troops are operating in the area.{{cite web | url=http://www.thechicagocouncil.org/sites/default/files/UkraineReport_February2015_FINAL.pdf | title=Preserving Ukraine's Independence, Resisting Russian Aggression: What the United States and NATO Must Do | publisher=Chicago Council on Global Affairs | date=2015 | accessdate=7 February 2015}} According to a military expert, Ilya Kramnik, total Ukrainian forces outnumber the Russian forces by a factor of two (20,000 Russian separatists vs. 40,000 fighting for Ukraine).{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-31164822 | title=Ukraine 'can't stop Russian armour' | publisher=BBC | date=6 February 2015 | accessdate=7 February 2015 | author=Laurence Peter}} In March 2015, [[Novaya Gazeta]] published an interview with a Russian soldier, Dorzhi Batomunkuev, who operated a tank in the [[Battle of Debaltseve]] and was wounded. He confirmed that the tanks came from his military unit in [[Ulan-Ude]] in Russia and that his unit "painted over the serial numbers and unit signs straight away on the rail platforms". In November 2014, Batomunkuev was sent as a conscript to [[Rostov-on-Don]], where he became a contract soldier. Traveling by train with his unit from Ulan-Ude, Batomunkuev said he saw "plenty of such trains" travelling along with them "day after day". After three months at Kosminskiy training facility, their unit of 31 tanks and 300 soldiers in total (mostly [[Buryats]]) was given an order to move on 8 February 2015 and crossed the Ukrainian border in the night, arriving in Donetsk in the morning. They took part in the battle on 12–14 February.{{cite web | url=http://www.interpretermag.com/ukraine-live-day-378-severely-injured-russian-soldier-describes-deployment-to-ukraine/#7227 | title=Severely Injured Russian Soldier Describes Deployment To Ukraine | publisher=The Interpreter Magazine | date=2 March 2015 | accessdate=3 March 2015}}{{cite web | url=https://meduza.io/en/feature/2015/03/02/a-bag-and-a-gun-and-it-was-into-the-tank | title='A bag and a gun, and it was into the tank' | publisher=Meduza | date=2 March 2015 | accessdate=2 March 2015}}{{cite web | url=http://www.novayagazeta.ru/society/67490.html | title=Мы все знали, на что идем и что может быть | work=Novaya Gazeta | date=2 March 2015 | accessdate=2 March 2015 | author=Elena Kostyuchenko |trans-title=We all knew where we are going|language=ru}} [[Joseph Kobzon]] met Batomunkuev in the same hospital a few days before the NG interview.{{cite web | url=http://zabmedia.ru/news/74274/mat_ranenogo_zabajkalca_kotorogo_navecshal_kobzon_otpravitsya_v_doneck/ | title=Мать раненого забайкальца, которого навещал Кобзон, отправится в Донецк | publisher=ZabMedia | date=27 February 2015 | accessdate=3 March 2015|language=ru}} In 2016 Alexander Minakov, another Russian soldier wounded in the battle of Debaltseve, was awarded a medal "For services to the Fatherland".{{Cite web|url=http://khpg.org/en/index.php?id=1489160612|title=Putin gives military award to Russian soldier for Donbas battle - Human Rights in Ukraine|website=khpg.org|access-date=2017-03-12}} A report by [[Igor Sutyagin]] published by the [[Royal United Services Institute]] in March 2015 stated that a total of 42,000 regular Russian combat troops have been involved in the fighting, with a peak strength of 10,000 in December 2014. The direct involvement of the Russian troops on Ukrainian territory began in August 2014, at a time when Ukrainian military successes created the possibility that the pro-Russian rebels would collapse. According to the report, the Russian troops are the most capable units on the anti-Ukrainian side, with the regular Donetsk and Luhansk rebel formations being used essentially as "cannon fodder".{{cite news|title=Scale of Russian military intervention in Ukraine revealed, says report|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/mar/11/russia-struggling-ukraine-military-operations-report|accessdate=11 March 2015|publisher=The Guardian}}{{cite web|url=https://www.rusi.org/downloads/assets/201503_BP_Russian_Forces_in_Ukraine_FINAL.pdf |title=Russian Forces in Ukraine |publisher=[[Royal United Services Institute]] |date=March 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150508220714/https://www.rusi.org/downloads/assets/201503_BP_Russian_Forces_in_Ukraine_FINAL.pdf |archivedate=8 May 2015 }} The [[Chicago Council on Global Affairs]] stated that the Russian separatists enjoyed technical advantages over the Ukrainian army since the large inflow of advanced military systems in mid-2014: effective anti-aircraft weapons ("Buk", MANPADS) suppressed Ukrainian air strikes, Russian drones provided intelligence, and Russian secure communications system thwarted the Ukrainian side from communications intelligence. The Russian side also frequently employed electronic warfare systems that Ukraine lacked. Similar conclusions about the technical advantage of the Russian separatists were voiced by the Conflict Studies Research Centre. In February 2015, the leading independent Russian newspaper ''[[Novaya Gazeta]]'' reported{{cite news | last=Lipsky|first= Andrey|url=http://www.novayagazeta.ru/politics/67389.html | title=Представляется правильным инициировать присоединение восточных областей Украины к России | date=25 February 2015 |accessdate= 11 April 2015| work=[[Novaya Gazeta]] | issue=19|language=ru}} that it had obtained documents, allegedly written by oligarch Konstantin Malofayev and others, which provided the Russian government with a strategy in the event of Viktor Yanukovych's removal from power and the break-up of Ukraine, which were considered likely. The documents outlined plans for the annexation of Crimea and the eastern portions of the country, closely describing the events that actually followed after Yanukovych's fall. The documents also described plans for a public relations campaign which would seek to justify Russian actions.{{cite web|last=Schofield |first=Matthew |url=http://www.mcclatchydc.com/2015/02/21/257386/russian-news-report-ukraine-invasion.html |title=BERLIN: Russian news report: Putin approved Ukraine invasion before Kiev government collapsed | Europe |publisher=McClatchy DC |date=22 February 2014 |accessdate=24 February 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/ukraine-rebels-agree-to-begin-withdrawing-weapons/2653786.html |title=Report to Allege Direct Kremlin Link to Ukraine Invasion |publisher=Voice of America |date=15 February 2014 |accessdate=24 February 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.inquisitr.com/1866019/world-war-3-vladimir-putin-plotted-ukraine-invasion-early-as-february-2014-new-report-says/ |title=World War 3: Vladimir Putin Plotted Ukraine Invasion Early As February 2014, New Report Says |publisher=Inquisitr.com |accessdate=24 February 2015}} In March 2015, a commander of the DPR special forces unit, Dmitry Sapozhnikov, gave an interview to the BBC{{cite web|title = Боец "спецназа ДНР" об участии России в войне на Украине - BBC Русская служба|url = http://www.bbc.com/russian/multimedia/2015/03/150331_v_dnr_spetsnaz_interwiev|website = BBC Русская служба|accessdate = 27 October 2015|language = ru}} in which he spoke openly about the involvement of Russian soldiers in the conflict. He described the arrival of Russian military vehicles and personnel from across the border as critical to the success of large-scale operations such as the [[battle of Debaltseve]]. Russian high-rank officers planned the operations and regular Russian army units with DPR forces carried them out jointly. In Sapozhnikov's opinion, "everyone knows that" and it's "no secret", but he was surprised to find out that it is not so widely acknowledged in Russia when he returned to Saint Petersburg.{{cite web | url=https://news.vice.com/article/russian-soldiers-have-given-up-pretending-they-are-not-fighting-in-ukraine | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402090708/https://news.vice.com/article/russian-soldiers-have-given-up-pretending-they-are-not-fighting-in-ukraine | archivedate=2015-04-02 | title=Russian Soldiers Have Given Up Pretending They Are Not Fighting in Ukraine | publisher=Vice News | date=31 March 2015 | accessdate=1 April 2015 |first=Alec |last= Luhn}} In April 2015, a group of Russian url=http://podrobnosti.ua/2029738-spetsnazovets-iz-tambova-kak-rossijskaja-armija-pereodevaetsja-pered-donbassom.html | title=Спецназовец из Тамбова: как россиян переодевают в "шахтеров" перед he found himself "not in an army, but in a gang", involved in large-scale looting. He also described the methods used by Russian army to covertly deliver military equipment, people and ammunition to Donbass, as well as hostile attitude of the local civilian population.{{cite web | url=http://uatoday.tv/politics/among-thugs-part-i-422256.html | title=Among the thugs | publisher=Ukraine Today | date=19 April 2015 | accessdate=24 April 2015 |first=Dmitry |last=Volchek }} On 22 April 2015, the [[US Department of State]] accused the "combined Russian-separatist forces" of accumulating air defence systems, UAV along with command and control equipment in eastern Ukraine, and of conducting "complex" military training that "leaves no doubt that Russia is involved in the training". Russia is also reinforcing its military presence on the eastern border with Ukraine as well as near Belgorod which is close to Kharkiv.{{cite web | url=http://moscow.usembassy.gov/harf-04222015.html | title=Statement by Marie Harf, Acting Spokesperson | publisher=US Department of State | date=22 April 2015 | accessdate=24 April 2015 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160201223519/http://moscow.usembassy.gov/harf-04222015.html | archivedate=1 February 2016 | df=dmy-all }} In May 2015, [[Reuters]] interviewed a number of Russian soldiers, some named and some speaking under condition of anonymity, who were serving in Donbass as truck drivers, crew of a T-72B3 tank and of a "Grad" launcher. Some of their colleagues resigned when asked to go to Donbass by their commanders, which was "not an easy decision" because the salary offered was between 20 and 60,000 rubles per month. The members of the "Grad" launcher crew confirmed they were shelling targets in Ukraine from Russian territory, around 2 km from the border.{{cite news | url=http://mobile.reuters.com/article/idUSKBN0NV06Q20150510?irpc=932 | title=Special Report: Russian soldiers quit over Ukraine | publisher=Reuters | date=10 May 2015 | accessdate=10 May 2015 |first=Maria |last= Tsvetkova}} Allies of [[Boris Nemtsov]] released ''[[Putin. War]]'', a report on Russian involvement that he had been working on before his death.{{cite report |url= http://4freerussia.org/putin.war/Putin.War-Eng.pdf |title= Putin. War – Based on materials from Boris Nemtsov |first= Boris |last= Nemtsov |authorlink1= Boris Nemtsov |first2= Ilya |last2= Yashin |first3= Olga |last3= Shorina |publisher= Free Russia Foundation |date= May 2015 }} * {{cite report|author=Boris Nemtsov|authorlink=Boris Nemtsov|url=http://www.libertas-institut.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/EUFAJ-Special-NemtsovReport-150521.pdf|format=PDF|title="Putin. The War", about the Involvement of Russia in the Eastern Ukraine conflict and the Crimea|publisher=European Union Foreign Affairs Journal|issue=Special Edition May 2015}} Other Russian opposition activists announced that they had found fresh graves of members of a GRU special forces brigade that had operated in Ukraine.{{cite news |url= https://news.yahoo.com/russian-activists-fresh-graves-soldiers-killed-ukraine-114424034.html |title=Russian activists say find fresh graves of soldiers killed in Ukraine |first= Maria |last= Antonova |work= Agence France-Presse |publisher= Yahoo News |date= 20 May 2015 }} In May, two GRU soldiers, Alexander Alexandrov and Yevgeny Yerofeyev, were captured alive in a battle near Schastie and were later interviewed by press, admitting to being on active duty at the time of capture. Russian military command declared they left active service in December 2014, a claim that was repeated on Russian television by the wife of Alexandrov.{{cite news |url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/05/29/us-ukraine-crisis-captured-specialreport-idUSKBN0OE0YE20150529|title = Special Report: Russian fighters, caught in Ukraine, cast adrift by Moscow|first = https://www.bellingcat.com/news/uk-and-europe/2015/06/13/the-russian-forpost-drone-shot-down-in-ukraine/ |title = Exclusive Access to the Russian Forpost Drone Shot Down in Ukraine |date = 13 June On 20 May 2015 members of the OSCE mission to Ukraine spoke with the Russian soldiers in the hospital.[https://web.archive.org/web/20150522013311/http://www.osce.org/ukraine-smm/159296 Latest from OSCE Special Monitoring Mission (SMM) to Ukraine based on information received as of 19:30 (Kyiv time), 20 May 2015]. [[OSCE]]. 20 May 2015 The OSCE 20 May 2015 report includes the following: {{quote|One of them said he had received orders from his military unit to go to Ukraine; he was to "rotate" after three months. Both of them said they had been to Ukraine "on missions" before.|author=[[OSCE]]|source=report of May 20, 2015}} In June 2015, ''[[Vice News]]'' reporter [[Simon Ostrovsky]] investigated the movements of Bato Dambaev, a Russian contract soldier from [[Buryatia]], through a military camp in [[Rostov Oblast]] to [[Vuhlehirsk]] in Ukraine during the [[battle of Debaltseve]] and back to Buryatia, finding exact locations where Dambaev photographed himself, and came to a conclusion that Dambaev had fought in Ukraine while in active service in the Russian army.{{cite web|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2zssIFN2mso|title = Selfie Soldiers: Russia Checks in to Ukraine|date = 16 June 2015|accessdate = |website = |publisher = VICE News|last = Ostrovsky|first = Simon}} With Russia refusing to allow the [[OSCE]] to expand its mission, OSCE observer Paul Picard stated that "We often see how Russian media outlets manipulate our statements. Nevertheless, evidence of its soldiers' involvement is rampant.{{Cite news|title=The unusual difficulty of tracking Russia's dead in Ukraine and Syria|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/checkpoint/wp/2015/10/27/the-unusual-difficulty-of-tracking-russias-dead-in-ukraine-and-syria/|date=27 October 2015|newspaper=The Washington Post|access-date=27 October 2015|first=Thomas|last=Gibbons-Neff}} OSCE monitoring mission has on numerous occasions spotted military convoys covertly crossing the border from Russia into Donbass,{{Cite web|url=https://www.rferl.org/a/osce-monitor-publishes-video-truck-convosy-between-russia-ukraine-first-evidence-illegal-crossings/29427195.html|title=Monitor Posts Video Of Truck Convoys Between Russia, Eastern Ukraine|website=RadioFreeEurope/RadioLiberty|language=en|access-date=2018-08-14}}{{Cite news|url=http://khpg.org/en/index.php?id=1537705092|title=More Russian military trucks caught entering Ukraine by night - The two men were later exchanged for captured Ukrainian pilot and politician [[Nadiya Savchenko]]{{cite web|url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/moscow-admits-two-fighters-captured-in-ukraine-are-ex-russian-soldiers/521093.html|title=Moscow Admits Two Fighters Captured in Ukraine Are Ex-Russian Soldiers|publisher=Moscow Times}} In July 2015 a Russian major was detained near Donetsk as he drove an ammunition truck into a Ukrainian checkpoint, the Russian military maintained the man was not involved with the Russian military and fought for local separatists. Открытие новогодней ёлки в Донецке 093.JPG|thumb|Russian citizen and Sparta Battalion commander [[Arseny Pavlov]] in Donetsk, 25 December 2014]] In 2015, [[NATO]] spokesman Robert Pszczel stated in an interview for [[Dozhd]] TV that the alliance has sufficient evidence to make "28 member states of the alliance have no doubts about military involvement of Russia" in the Donbass conflict.{{cite web|url=http://tvrain.ru/teleshow/lobkov_vechernee_shou/robert_pshel_u_nato_uzhe_mnogo_mesjatsev_est_dokazatelstva_voennoj_podderzhki_separatistov_iz_rossii-381602/|script-title=ru:Роберт Пшель: "У НАТО уже много месяцев есть доказательства военной поддержки сепаратистов из России"|trans-title=Robert Pshel: "NATO has had evidence of Russian military support to separatists for many months"|language=ru|publisher=TV Rain|date=5 February 2015|accessdate=5 February 2015}} In a battle at Donetsk airport at least 31 of the people killed were Russian citizens and were delivered back to Russia.{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jun/27/ukraine-donetsk-airport-russia-fighter|title=Battle for Donetsk airport: the story of one Russian fighter|last=Rostov-on-Don|first=Elena Kostyuchenko in|last2=Gazeta|first2=for Novaya|date=2014-06-27|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-01-30}} A report for the independent news site ''Novaya Gazeta'', reprinted in ''[[The Guardian]]'', tracked down the widow of one Russian man who died during the fighting at Donetsk airport, and sought to shed light onto the obscure structures that organised the transfer of fighters to Ukraine. The report further highlighted the 'frustration of dealing with Russian officialdom apparently so keen to cover up all traces of those fighting across the border'.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jun/27/ukraine-donetsk-airport-russia-fighter|title=Battle for Donetsk airport: the story of one Russian fighter|work=the Guardian|accessdate= 11 April 2015}} [[File:Aleksandr Zakharchenko takes an oath of office as the PM of Donetsk People's Republic.jpg|thumb|[[Aleksandr Zakharchenko]] takes an oath of office as the Prime Minister of [[Donetsk People's Republic]], 8 August 2014. In August too he said 1200 fighters trained in Russia for four months, crossed and were ready to fight. He said the reinforcements included 30 tanks and 120 armoured vehicles.{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/10867312-2560-11e4-af2c-00144feabdc0,Authorised=false.html?_i_location=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ft.com%2Fcms%2Fs%2F0%2F10867312-2560-11e4-af2c-00144feabdc0.html%3Fsiteedition%3Duk&siteedition=uk&_i_referer=http%3A%2F%2Fsearch.aol.co.uk%2Faol%2Fsearch%3Fs_it%3Dtopsearchbox.search%26s_chn%3Dhp_t1%26v_t%3Daoluk-homePage51%26as_qdr%3D%26q%3Dfinancial%2Btimes%2Brebel%2Bleader%2Bin%2Bukraine%2Bboasts%2Bof%2B#axzz3AZvjvrit|title=Separatist leader boasts of fresh tanks and trained troops from Russia|work=Financial Times|accessdate= 11 April 2015}}]] [[Alexander Zakharchenko]] said that 1200 fighters had trained in Russia for four months, crossed the border, and were ready to fight. Zakharchenko said the reinforcements included 30 tanks and 120 armoured vehicles. He later denied making the comments.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/08/20/uk-ukraine-crisis-rebelranks-insight-idAFKBN0GK0NO20140820|title=Insight - Ukraine rebel movement faces uncertain future|work=Reuters|accessdate= 11 April 2015|date=20 August 2014}} Cases of Russian soldiers killed and wounded in Ukraine are widely discussed in local Russian media in the republics from which they originated.{{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jan/19/russia-official-silence-for-families-troops-killed-in-ukraine | title=They were never there: Russia's silence for families of troops killed in Ukraine | publisher=Guardian | date=19 January 2015 | accessdate=20 January 2015 | author=Alec Luhn}} Recruitment for Donbass is performed rather openly via veteran and other paramilitary organisations. Vladimir Yefimov, leader of one of such organisations, explained in details in an interview how the process works in [[Ural (region)|Ural]] area. The organisation recruits mostly army veterans, but also policemen, firefighters etc. with military experience. The cost of equipping one volunteer is estimated at around 350,000 [[Russian ruble|rubles]] (around $6500) plus cost of the volunteer's salary from 60,000 to 240,000 rubles per month depending on their experience. The volunteers are issued a document claiming that their participation is limited to "offering humanitarian help" to avoid Russian [[mercenary]] laws. In Russia's anti-mercenary legislation a mercenary is defined as someone who "takes part [in fighting] with aims counter to the interests of the Russian Federation".[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/kyiv-post-plus/russia-trolls-world-by-saying-it-cannot-stop-its-citizens-from-fighting-in-ukraine-392006.html Russia trolls world by saying it cannot stop its citizens from fighting in Ukraine], [[Kyiv Post]] (25 June 2015) The recruited travel to the conflict zone without weapons, which are given at the destination. Often, Russian troops have travelled disguised as Red Cross personnel.{{cite web | url=http://www.newsweek.com/how-russians-are-sent-fight-ukraine-296937 | title=How Russians Are Sent to Fight in url=http://www.interpretermag.com/russians-used-humanitarian-convoys-to-send-militants-into-ukraine-russian-organizer-of-this-effort-says/ | title=Russians Used Humanitarian Convoys to Send Militants A significant proportion were people in difficult financial situations, attracted by a high salary (one of the volunteers was promised 100,000 rubles or $1600). Responding to concerns about crossing the Ukrainian border, he explained that "there is a green light for the volunteers on the border" and "all that is covered by appropriate structures". The family of a killed volunteer, when asking about help in bringing back the body, is advised to "speak to the [[Federal Security Service|FSB]], only they are controlling everything there".{{cite web | url=http://tvrain.ru/teleshow/reportazh/kto_verbuet_rossijskih_dobrovoltsev_i_chto_im_obeschajut_istorija_odnogo_naemnika_ekskljuziv_dozhdja-382605/ | title=Кто вербует российских добровольцев, и что им обещают. Эксклюзив Дождя | language=ru| publisher=TV Rain | date=26 February 2015 | accessdate=2 March 2015 | author=Sergey Erzhenkov}} Shortly before [[Assassination of Boris Nemtsov|his death]], [[Boris Nemtsov]] was reportedly contacted by a group of "paratroopers from [[Ivanovo]]" who complained about significant losses in their unit during a battle in Ukraine and the lack of the promised payment. web|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/parallels/2014/09/08/346735504/some-in-russia-admit-their-troops-volunteer-in-ukraine|title=Russia Reports Troop Deaths in Ukraine, But Calls Them Reali | date=4 September 2014 | accessdate=5 September 2014 |trans-title=Russia's unrecognized soldiers}}{{cite web|url=http://www.tv100.ru/news/ischeznuvshij-desant-99022/ |title=Исчезнувший десант |publisher='100 TV |date=5 September 2014 |accessdate=5 September 2014 |trans-title=Disappeared paratroopers |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140904012354/http://www.tv100.ru/news/ischeznuvshij-desant-99022/ |archivedate=4 September 2014 }} On 2 October 2014, [[RBC Information Systems|RBC]] published ''An RBC investigation: Where Russian soldiers in Ukraine are from'', in which it listed Russian military divisions, soldiers of which are assumed to have been secretly dispatched from Russia to Ukraine and used there.{{cite web|author=Максим Солопов|script-title=ru:Расследование РБК: откуда на Украине российские солдаты|url=http://top.rbc.ru/politics/02/10/2014/542c0dcfcbb20f5d06c1d87a|publisher=[[RBC Information Systems|RBC]]|language=ru|date=2 October 2014 |accessdate= 11 April 2015}} In 2015, [[Vice News]] published a series titled ''Russia's Ghost Army in Ukraine'' in which they spoke to a number of families of Russian soldiers killed in Ukraine. All of the mother's questions to her son's commanders were dismissed as a "state secret" and she was told that she would receive compensation of 100,000 rubles ($1600).{{cite web | url=https://news.vice.com/video/russias-ghost-army-in-ukraine-part-2 | title=Russia's Ghost Army in Ukraine (Part 2) | publisher=Vice News | date=4 March 2015 | accessdate=4 March 2015}} On 16 October 2014, the deputy chief of the [[Security Service of Ukraine]] said that the service had released 16 out of 131 servicemen of the [[Armed Forces of Russian Federation]] back home to their relatives who petitioned through a hotline.[http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2014/10/16/7041038/ Ukraine has released to their relatives 16 Russian military servicemen]. [[Ukrayinska Pravda]]. 16 October 2014 According to soldiers' rights advocates, the families of Russian soldiers killed after being sent to Ukraine have been told to keep silent, and some families say they have not received the various compensations they are entitled to after a breadwinner in military service has been killed.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jan/19/russia-official-silence-for-families-troops-killed-in-ukraine|title=They were never there: Russia's silence for families of troops killed in Ukraine|author=Alec Luhn|work=the Guardian|accessdate= 11 April 2015}} Svetlana Davydova, a mother of seven, was arrested in 2015, accused of treason for calling the Ukrainian embassy about Russian troop movements, and was held at the high-security [[Lefortovo jail]] in Moscow. The Russian General Staff said details of the case constituted a "state secret". The charges against Davydova were dropped the following month. An amendment signed by Putin in late May 2015 banned information about the deaths of Russian servicemen "during special operations" in peacetime.{{cite news |url= http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/putin-classifying-troop-losses-proves-theyre-in-ukraine--analysts/522577.html |title=Putin Classifying Troop Losses Proves They're in Ukraine – Analysts |first= Ivan |last= Nechepurenko |work= [[The Moscow Times]] |date= 28 May 2015 }}{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-32913929 |title=Putin declares Russian troop deaths in peacetime a secret |work= BBC News |date= 28 May 2015 }} Discussing Russian volunteers in an interview with [[RIA Novosti]] on 22 June 2015, [[Nikolai Patrushev]], secretary of the [[Security Council of Russia]], stated: "We don't call on anyone to do this, we don't encourage it. But realistically, to stop them would be impossible". While Russia has charged one of its citizens, Roman Zheleznov, for fighting in the Ukrainian [[Azov Battalion]], as of 25 June 2015, it has charged no one for fighting alongside the separatists. Since counting began on 1 September 2014 until 1 June 2015, the European monitoring mission on the Russian side of the border has recorded 20,021 men in military uniforms crossing to and from rebel-controlled eastern Ukraine.{{Cite news|title = Russian Town Near Ukraine, Once Quiet, Now Buzzes With Military Activity|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/20/world/europe/russian-town-near-ukraine-once-quiet-now-buzzes-with-military-activity.html|newspaper = The New York Times|date = 19 July 2015|access-date = 21 July 2015|issn = 0362-4331|first = Andrew E.|last = Kramer}} In July 2015, a number of Russian contract soldiers at "Kadamovskiy" poligon ([[Rostov Oblast|Rostovskaya oblast]]) were charged with [[desertion]] after they refused to go into Ukraine as "volunteers". They reported frequent visits of recruiters promising veteran status and daily payment of 8,000 rubles for those fighting in Donbass. They said they were unaware that the money is rarely paid and in case of death, capture or injury in battle they will be most likely abandoned and their official military status denied by Russian army.{{cite web|title = Russian soldiers face prison for refusing to fight in Ukraine :: khpg.org|url = http://khpg.org/index.php?id=1436617897|website = khpg.org|accessdate = 12 July 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Koshik|first1=Andrey|last2=Dergachyov|first2=Vladimir|last3=Maetnaya|first3=Yelizaveta|title = Я не хотел участвовать в боевых действиях на территории Украины|url = http://www.gazeta.ru/politics/2015/07/10_a_7633125.shtml|date=11 July 2015|accessdate = 12 July 2015|language=ru}} Later that year they were convicted for "refusal to carry out orders" in spite of lack of any orders presented by the prosecution and other inconsistencies.{{cite web|title = Где война, там и Россия|url = https://tvrain.ru/teleshow/reportazh/gde_vojna_tam_i_rossija-397059/|website = tvrain.ru|publisher = TV Rain|accessdate = 27 October 2015|language=ru}} In September 2015 [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe|OSCE]] monitoring mission spotted Russian [[TOS-1|TOS-1 "Buratino"]] thermobaric weapon launchers in separatist training area near Lugansk{{cite web|title = Latest from OSCE Special Monitoring Mission (SMM) to Ukraine based on information received as of 27 September 2015 - OSCE|url = http://www.osce.org/ukraine-smm/186276|website = www.osce.org|accessdate = 1 October 2015}} and in June 2016 its drone spotted a camouflaged R-330ZH "Zhitel" [[electronic countermeasure]] station 15 km from Donetsk, these findings being notable as both weapons are unique to the army of Russian Federation.{{Cite web|url=http://uatoday.tv/politics/osce-spots-russian-electronic-warfare-stations-in-donbas-675936.html|title=OSCE spots Russian electronic warfare stations in Donbas|website=uatoday.tv|access-date=2016-06-20}} By October 2015, eastern Ukraine and Crimea were two of Russia's [[Frozen conflict|frozen zones]].{{cite news |last1=STACK |first1=LIAM |last2=ZRAICK |first2=KAREN |date=14 October 2015 |title=Frozen Zones: How Russia Maintains Influence in the Post-Cold War Era |url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/10/14/world/europe/russia-frozen-zones-syria.html |newspaper=The New York Times |access-date=21 October 2015 }} The chances were that the frozen conflict might persist in the Donbass, where the fighting was at a low level, but the threat of escalation remained.{{cite news |last=Burridge |first=Tom |date=23 October 2015 |title=Ukraine conflict: Guns fall silent but crisis remains |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34606598 |newspaper= BBC News |location=Ukraine |access-date=22 October 2015 }}[http://thepoliticon.net/analytics/291-ukraine-towards-a-frozen-future.html Rusif Huseynov. (...) Would it be acceptable for Russia, considering its international standing, to keep mum and recognise the coup in Ukraine, and to leave Russians and Russian speakers in Ukraine in the lurch after the first order issued by the organisers of the anti-constitutional armed revolt, which was supported by their foreign sponsors, banned many things that were connected with the Russian language?|sign=[[Sergey Lavrov]]|source=Primakov Readings International Forum, Moscow, June 30, 2017}} ====Russian medal count==== Citizen journalist [[Eliot Higgins]] has pointed to the unusual spike in medals awarded to Russian troops coinciding with major battles occurring in Ukraine. It was noticed that between 25 August 2003 and 7 November 2014 there was 0.6 medals ''For Distinction in Combat'' awarded to Russian servicemen per day. However, between 7 November 2014 and 18 February 2016 there was an average of 9.3 medals awarded per day, over a fifteenfold increase. Moreover, the award dates directly coincide with major conflicts occurring in Ukraine at the time. August 2014 sees an initial spike of 60 medal per day being awarded, which coincides with reports of regular Russian troops crossing into Ukraine to aid separatist forces. The medal awards peak during November and December 2014, at over 70 per day, which was a crucial turning point during the [[Second Battle of Donetsk Airport]], continuing to remain at over 10 medals per day until March 2015, which coincides with the [[Battle of Debaltseve]]. Also important to note is that the medal ''For Distinction in Combat'' may only be awarded for activities undertaken during a combat mission, therefore the large spike in medals awarded in late 2014 and early 2015 suggests a large contingent of Russian servicemen undertaking combat missions. In all 4300 medals were awarded between 7 July 2014 and 18 February 2016, suggesting combat operations involving active duty Russian military personnel occurred during the time period. Likewise spikes in awarding other medals were seen as well. The medal ''For Courage'' which was awarded at a rate of 1.4 medals per day between September 2008 and August 2014 increased to 6.3 medals per day between August 2014 and November 2015. The ''[[Medal of Suvorov]]'' saw an increase of award rate from 1.5 medals per day between October 2013 and November 2014 to 6.8 medals per day after November 2014. In fact in the time period between 24 November 2014 and 25 January 2015 more of the medals were awarded then all of 2013 combined.{{cite web|url=https://www.bellingcat.com/news/uk-and-europe/2016/08/31/russias-war-ukraine-medals-treacherous-numbers/|title=Russia's War in Ukraine: The medals and Treacherous Numbers|publisher=Bellingcat}} ====Training facility==== In a press briefing by the Ukrainian Secretary of the National Security and Defence Council (NSDC), [[Andriy Parubiy]] stated that militants were trained in a military facility in [[Rostov-on-Don]], Russia. "Near Rostov-on-Don, there is a big military base where terrorists are preparing for deployment into the territory of the Ukrainian state. This is confirmed not only by our intelligence, but also Russian prisoners who were detained, and they testify about this base," Parubiy said. He added that more than a thousand militants are trained by Russian instructors, and then they in small armed groups try to break into the territory of Ukraine.{{cite web|url=http://www.ukrinform.ua/eng/news/terrorists_for_ukraine_trained_in_rostov_on_don_parubiy_says_321765|title=Terrorists for Ukraine trained in Rostov-on-Don, Parubiy says- Ukrinform|publisher=|accessdate=14 October 2014}} On 21 May, Ukraine detained a Russian citizen trying to enter the country; he had military experience and was found to have recently trained in the Rostov facility.{{cite web|url=http://www.unian.net/politics/920457-v-harkove-zaderjali-snaypera-dvuh-chechenskih-kampaniy.html|script-title=ru:В Харькове задержали снайпера двух чеченских Travelling through Moscow, they were met by a "government official" and sent to Donetsk, where they were provided with accommodation, uniforms and weapons, but they fought as volunteers. They stated there are "a few hundreds" of Western volunteers, mostly from [[Serbia]] and [[France]], "half of them communists, half Nazis", fighting jointly for the "liberation of Russia from Ukrainian invasion".{{cite web | url=http://elpais.com/elpais/2015/02/27/inenglish/1425051026_915897.html | title=We fought together, communists and Nazis alike, for the liberation of Russia | publisher=El Pais | date=27 February 2015 | accessdate=5 March 2015 | author=Patricia Ortega Dolz}} ====Governance==== In March 2016, Germany's [[Bild]] reported that minutes from an October 2015 meeting of the "Interministerial Commission for the Provision of Humanitarian Aid for the Affected Areas of the Southeast of the Donetsk and Lugansk Regions" indicated that Russia was running militant-controlled parts of east Ukraine. According to Bild, "It is notable that no members of the self-declared people's republics in eastern Ukraine are on the commission".{{cite news |url= http://www.bild.de/politik/ausland/ukraine-konflikt/donbass-shadow-government-45102202.bild.html |title= Secret document exposes Putin's shadow government for Donbass |work= [[Bild]] |date= 29 March 2016 }} ==Reactions to the Russian invasion in Crimea== {{main|International reactions to the annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation}} {{See also|Cold War II}} ===Ukrainian response=== Interim Ukrainian President [[Oleksandr Turchynov]] accused Russia of "provoking a conflict" by backing the seizure of the Crimean parliament building and other government offices on the Crimean peninsula. He compared Russia's military actions to the 2008 [[Russo-Georgian War]], when Russian troops occupied parts of the [[Georgia (country)|Republic of Georgia]] and the breakaway enclaves of [[Abkhazia]] and [[South Ossetia]] were established under the control of Russian-backed administrations. He called on Putin to withdraw Russian troops from Crimea and stated that Ukraine will "preserve its territory" and "defend its independence".{{cite news|url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine-abroad/turchynov-russia-waging-war-of-aggression-in-crimea-337972.html|work=Kyiv Post|title=Turchynov: Russia starts aggression in Crimea|date=28 February 2014|accessdate=1 March 2014}} On 1 March, he warned, "Military intervention would be the beginning of war and the end of any relations between Ukraine and Russia."{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/10669670/Ukraine-live-Crimea-leader-appeals-to-Putin-to-help-as-Obama-warns-of-costs-to-Moscow.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140302002603/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/ukraine/10669670/Ukraine-live-Crimea-leader-appeals-to-Putin-to-help-as-Obama-warns-of-costs-to-Moscow.html|archivedate=2 1237-VII of 6 May 2014) - News from Ukraine's diplomatic missions - MFA of Ukraine|website=mfa.gov.ua|language=en|access-date=2017-02-25}} On 16 September 2015 the [[Ukrainian parliament]] voted for
