{{EngvarB|date=July 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} {{Infobox scientist |name = William Whiston |image = William Whiston.png |caption = William Whiston (1667–1752) |birth_date = {{birth date|1667|12|09|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Twycross|Norton-juxta-Twycross]], [[Leicestershire]], England |death_date = {{death date and age|1752|08|22|1667|12|09|df=y}} |death_place = [[Lyndon, Rutland]], England |residence = [[Kingdom of Great Britain]] |citizenship = |nationality = English |fields = [[Mathematics|Mathematician]], theologian |workplaces = [[Clare College, Cambridge]] |alma_mater = [[Clare College, Cambridge]] |doctoral_advisor = |academic_advisors = [[Isaac Newton]]
[[Robert Herne]] |doctoral_students = |notable_students = [[James Jurin]] |known_for = Translating the [[Josephus#Works|works of Josephus]], [[catastrophism]], [[Isoclinic line|isoclinic maps]], work on [[longitude]] |influences = [[David Gregory (mathematician)|David Gregory]]
[[Isaac Newton]] |influenced = |awards = |signature = WilliamWhiston_sig.jpg |footnotes = }} '''William Whiston''' (9 December 1667 – 22 August 1752) was an English theologian, historian, and mathematician, a leading figure in the popularisation of the ideas of [[Isaac Newton]]. He is now probably best known for helping to instigate the [[Longitude Act]] in 1714 (and his attempts to win [[longitude prize|the rewards]] that it promised) and his important translations of the ''[[Antiquities of the Jews]]'' and other works by [[Josephus]] (which are still in print). He was a prominent exponent of [[Arianism]] and wrote ''[[A New Theory of the Earth]]''. Whiston succeeded his mentor Newton as [[Lucasian Professor of Mathematics]] at the [[University of Cambridge]]. In 1710 he lost the professorship and was expelled from the university as a result of his unorthodox religious views. Because Whiston recognized the Bible as a book of spiritual truth, he rejected the notion of eternal torment in hellfire. He viewed it as absurd and cruel, as well as an insult to God. What especially pitted him against church authorities, was he viewed the [[Trinity]] as a lie after extensive research convinced him the origin of the Trinity teaching to be pagan. ==Early life and career== Whiston was born to Josiah Whiston and Katherine Rosse at [[Twycross|Norton-juxta-Twycross]], in [[Leicestershire]], where his father was [[Rector (ecclesiastical)|rector]]. He was educated privately, for his health, and so that he could act as [[amanuensis]] to his blind father.{{EB1911|inline=1 |wstitle=Whiston, William |volume=28}} He studied at [[Queen Elizabeth's Mercian School|Queen Elizabeth Grammar School]], [[Tamworth, Staffordshire|Tamworth]]. After his father's death, he entered [[Clare College, Cambridge]] as a [[sizar]] on 30 June 1686. He applied himself to mathematical study, was awarded the degree of Bachelor of Arts (BA) (1690), and AM (1693), and was elected Fellow in 1691 and probationary senior Fellow in 1693.{{acad|id=WHSN686W|name=Whiston, William}} [[William Lloyd (bishop of Worcester)|William Lloyd]] ordained Whiston at [[Lichfield]] in 1693. In 1694, claiming ill health, he resigned his tutorship at Clare to [[Richard Laughton]], chaplain to [[John Moore (Bishop of Norwich)|John Moore]], the [[bishop of Norwich]], and swapped positions with him. He now divided his time between Norwich, Cambridge and London. In 1698 Moore gave him the living of [[Lowestoft]] where he became rector. In 1699 he resigned his Fellowship of Clare College and left to marry. In 1701 Whiston resigned his living to become Isaac Newton's substitute, giving the Lucasian lectures at Cambridge. He succeeded Newton as Lucasian professor in 1702. There followed a period of joint research with [[Roger Cotes]], appointed with Whiston's patronage to the [[Plumian professorship]] in 1706. Students at the Cotes–Whiston experimental philosophy course included [[Stephen Hales]], [[William Stukeley]], and [[Joseph Wasse]].{{cite book |last=Knox |first=Kevin C. |title=From Newton to Hawking: A History of Cambridge University's Lucasian Professors of Mathematics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QGX_rAeia4kC&pg=PA145|accessdate=28 May 2013|date=6 November 2003|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-66310-6|page=145}} ==Newtonian theologian== [[File:WilliamWhistonComet.jpg|thumb|left|A portrait of William Whiston with a diagram demonstrating his theories of cometary catastrophism, described in ''[[A New Theory of the Earth]]'']] In 1707 Whiston was [[Boyle lecturer]]; this lecture series was at the period a significant opportunity for Newton's followers, including [[Richard Bentley]] and [[Samuel Clarke]], to express their views, especially in opposition to the rise of [[deism]].{{cite book |last=Shank |first=J. B. |title=The Newton Wars and the Beginning of the French Enlightenment|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BBusxgu8-AAC&pg=PA128|accessdate=22 May 2013|date=15 September 2008|publisher=University of Chicago Press|isbn=978-0-226-74947-1|pages=128–9}} The "Newtonian" line came to include, with Bentley, Clarke and Whiston in particular, a defence of [[natural law]] by returning to the definition of [[Augustine of Hippo]] of a [[miracle]] (a cause of human wonderment), rather than the prevailing concept of a divine intervention against nature, which went back to [[Anselm of Canterbury|Anselm]]. This move was intended to undermine arguments of deists and sceptics.{{cite book |last=Shaw |first=Jane |title=Miracles in Enlightenment England|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4_UXe_Cat7wC&pg=PA31|accessdate=22 May 2013|year=2006|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=978-0-300-11272-6|page=31 and 171}} The Boyle lectures dwelt on the connections between biblical prophecies, dramatic physical events such as floods and eclipses, and their explanations in terms of science.{{ThoemmesBritish17C|Whiston, William|875}} On the other hand, Whiston was alive to possible connections of prophecy with current affairs: the [[War of the Spanish Succession]], and later the [[Jacobite rebellions]].{{cite book|author1=Sara Schechner|author2=Sara Schechner Genuth|title=Comets, popular culture, and the birth of modern cosmology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_U3rRP-P684C&pg=PA292|accessdate=23 May 2013|year=1999|publisher=Princeton University Press|isbn=978-0-691-00925-4|page=292}} Whiston supported a qualified [[biblical literalism]]: the literal meaning should be the default, unless there was a good reason to think otherwise.{{cite book |last=Kidd |first=Colin |title=British Identities before Nationalism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=I2EIlJISeUMC&pg=PA45|accessdate=22 May 2013|year=1999|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-139-42572-8|page=45}} This view again went back to Augustine. Newton's attitude to the [[cosmogony]] of [[Thomas Burnet]] reflected on the language of the [[Genesis creation narrative]]; as did Whiston's alternative cosmogony. Moses as author of ''Genesis'' was not necessarily writing as a natural philosopher, nor as a law-giver, but for a particular audience.{{cite book |last=Poole |first=William |title=The World Makers: Scientists of the Restoration and the Search for the Origins of the Earth|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=--Z4LNo40cwC&pg=PA68|accessdate=22 May 2013|year=2010|publisher=Peter Lang|isbn=978-1-906165-08-6|page=68}} The new cosmogonies of Burnet, Whiston and [[John Woodward (naturalist)|John Woodward]] were all criticised for their disregard of the biblical account, by [[John Arbuthnot]], [[John Edwards (divine)|John Edwards]] and [[William Nicolson]] in particular.{{cite book|author1=[[Stephen Gaukroger]]|author2=John Schuster|author3=John Sutton|title=Descartes' Natural Philosophy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lguESFLTOl0C&pg=PA176|accessdate=23 May 2013|date=1 November 2002|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-0-203-46301-7|pages=176–7}} The title for Whiston's Boyle lectures was ''The Accomplishment of Scripture Prophecies''. Rejecting [[typology (theology)|typological]] interpretation of biblical prophecy, he argued that the meaning of a prophecy must be unique. His views were later challenged by [[Anthony Collins]].{{cite book|editor=Henk J. M. Nellen|author3=Edwin Rabbie|title=Hugo Grotius, Theologian: Essays in Honour of G. H. M. Posthumus Meyjes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nULvj0SoH6sC&pg=PA195|accessdate=22 May 2013|year=1994|publisher=BRILL|isbn=978-90-04-10000-8|page=195}} There was a more immediate attack by [[Nicholas Clagett the younger|Nicholas Clagett]] in 1710.{{cite DNB|wstitle=Clagett, Nicholas (1654-1727)|display=Clagett, Nicholas (1654–1727)|volume=10}} One reason prophecy was topical was the [[Camisard]] movement that saw French exiles ("French prophets") in England. Whiston had started writing on the [[millenarianism]] that was integral to the Newtonian theology, and wanted to distance his views from theirs, and in particular from those of [[John Lacy (merchant)|John Lacy]].{{cite book|author1=Jed Zachary Buchwald|author2=Mordechai Feingold|title=Newton and the origin of civilization|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wmFGvVvwon0C&pg=PA336|accessdate=22 May 2013|date=22 October 2012|publisher=Princeton University Press|isbn=978-0-691-15478-7|page=336}} Meeting the French prophets in 1713, Whiston developed the view that the [[charismatic gift]] of revelation could be [[demonic possession]].{{cite book|author1=J.E. Force|author2=S. Hutton|title=Newton and Newtonianism: New Studies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oKT9HfHQ5tEC&pg=PA179|accessdate=25 May 2013|year=2004|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-1-4020-1969-2|page=179 note 102.}} ==Tensions with Newton== It is no longer assumed that Whiston's ''Memoirs'' are completely trustworthy on the matter of his personal relations with Newton. One view is that the relationship was never very close, Bentley being more involved in Whiston's appointment to the Lucasian chair; and that it deteriorated as soon as Whiston began to write on prophecy, publishing ''Essay on the Revelation of St John'' (1706). This work proclaimed the millennium for the year 1716.{{cite book |last=Jacob |first=Margaret C. |title=The Newtonians and the English Revolution 1689–1720 |year=1976 |publisher=Harvester Press |pages=132–3}} Whiston's 1707 edition of Newton's ''[[Arithmetica Universalis]]'' did nothing to improve matters. Newton himself was heavily if covertly involved in the 1722 edition, nominally due to [[John Machin]], making many changes.{{cite book|editor=D. T. Whiteside|title=The Mathematical Papers of Isaac Newton:|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sf5z2h93_wcC&pg=PA14|accessdate=22 May 2013|date=3 January 2008|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-04584-1|page=14}} In 1708–9 Whiston was engaging [[Thomas Tenison]] and [[John Sharp (bishop)|John Sharp]] as archbishops in debates on the Trinity. There is evidence from [[Hopton Haynes]] that Newton reacted by pulling back from publication on the issue;{{cite book|author1=J.E. Force|author2=S. Hutton|title=Newton and Newtonianism: New Studies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oKT9HfHQ5tEC&pg=PA109|accessdate=25 May 2013|year=2004|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-1-4020-1969-2|page=109}} his [[antitrinitarian]] views, from the 1690s, were finally published in 1754 as ''[[An Historical Account of Two Notable Corruptions of Scripture]]''. Whiston was never a Fellow of the [[Royal Society]]. In conversation with [[Edmond Halley]] he blamed his reputation as a "heretick". Also, though, he claimed Newton had disliked having an independent-minded disciple; and was unnaturally cautious and suspicious by nature.{{cite book |editor=[[Richard H. Popkin]] |title=The Pimlico History of Western Philosophy |year=1999 |publisher=Pimlico |isbn=0-7126-6534-X |page=427}} ==Expelled Arian== Whiston's route to rejection of the [[Nicene Creed]], the historical orthodox position against [[Arianism]], began early in his tenure of the Lucasian chair as he followed hints from Samuel Clarke. He read also in [[Louis Ellies Dupin]], and the ''Explication of Gospel Theism'' (1706) of [[Richard Brocklesby (clergyman)|Richard Brocklesby]].{{cite book|last=Wiles |first=Maurice |authorlink=Maurice Wiles|title=Archetypal Heresy: Arianism Through the Centuries|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gKWjIQtq5gQC&pg=PA94|accessdate=22 May 2013|date=26 September 1996|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-826927-4|pages=94–}} His study of the ''[[Apostolic Constitutions]]'' then convinced him that Arianism was the creed of the early church. The [[British general election, 1710|general election of 1710]] brought the [[Tories (British political party)|Tories]] solid political power for a number of years, up to the [[Hanoverian succession]] of 1714. Their distrust of theological innovation had a direct impact on Whiston, as well as others of similar views. His [[heterodoxy]] was notorious.{{cite book |last=Gibson |first=William |title=The Enlightenment Prelate: Benjamin Hoadly, 1767-1761|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DepggDo4awIC&pg=PA121|accessdate=22 May 2013|year=2004|publisher=James Clarke & Co.|isbn=978-0-227-67978-4|pages=121–3}} In 1710 he was deprived of his professorship and expelled from the university. The matter was not allowed to rest there: Whiston tried to get a hearing before [[Convocation of the English Clergy|Convocation]]. He did have defenders even in the [[high church]] ranks, such as [[George Smalridge]].{{cite book|author1=William Gibson|author2=Robert G.. Ingram|title=Religious Identities in Britain: 1660 – 1832|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gX5Mc_5snlcC&pg=PA47|accessdate=22 May 2013|year=2005|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.|isbn=978-0-7546-3209-2|pages=47–8}} For political reasons, this development would have been divisive at the time. [[Anne, Queen of Great Britain|Queen Anne]] made a point of twice "losing" the papers in the case.{{cite book|author1=Dr William Gibson|author2=William Gibson|title=The Church of England 1688–1832: Unity and Accord|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qyel0pA36JgC&pg=PA81|accessdate=22 May 2013|date=4 January 2002|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-0-203-13462-7|page=81}} After her death in 1714 the intended hearing was allowed to drop.{{cite DNB|wstitle=Whiston, William|display=Whiston, William|volume=61}} The party passions of these years found an echo in [[Henry Sacheverell]]'s attempt to exclude Whiston from his church of [[St Andrew's, Holborn]], taking place in 1719.{{cite book |last=Steele |first=John M. |title=Ancient Astronomical Observations and the Study of the Moon's Motion (1691–1757)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rAuWlfyMGLkC&pg=PA24|accessdate=22 May 2013|year=2012|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-1-4614-2149-8|page=24}} =="Primitive Christianity"== [[File:WilliamWhiston.jpg|thumb|right]] Whiston founded a society for promoting primitive Christianity, lecturing in support of his theories in halls and [[coffee house|coffee-houses]] at London, [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]], and [[Tunbridge Wells]]. Those he involved included [[Thomas Chubb]],{{cite ODNB|id=5378|title=Chubb, Thomas|first=Clive|last=Probyn}} [[Thomas Emlyn]],{{cite ODNB|id=8793|title=Emlyn, Thomas|first=H. J.|last=McLachlan}} [[John Gale (theologian)|John Gale]],{{cite ODNB|id=10292|title=Gale, John|first=Jim|last=Benedict}} [[Benjamin Hoadley]],{{cite book |last=Force |first=James E. |title=William Whiston: Honest Newtonian|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dc6Zk-HvIwwC&pg=PA27|accessdate=21 May 2013|date=20 June 2002|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-52488-9|page=27}} [[Arthur Onslow]], and [[Thomas Rundle]].{{cite ODNB|id=24279|title=Rundle, Thomas|first=Alan R.|last=Acheson}} There were meetings at Whiston's house from 1715 to 1717; Hoadley avoided coming, as did Samuel Clarke, though invited.{{cite book |last=Sheehan |first=Jonathan |title="The" Enlightenment Bible: Translation, Scholarship, Culture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SJGhYCqVflUC&pg=PA35|accessdate=22 May 2013|year=2005|publisher=Princeton University Press|isbn=978-0-691-11887-1|page=35 note 21}} A meeting with Clarke, Hoadley, [[John Craig (mathematician)|John Craig]] and Gilbert Burnet the younger had left these leading [[latitudinarian]]s unconvinced about Whiston's reliance on the ''Apostolical Constitutions''.{{cite book |last=Gibson |first=William |title=The Enlightenment Prelate: Benjamin Hoadly, 1767-1761|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DepggDo4awIC&pg=PA122|accessdate=22 May 2013|year=2004|publisher=James Clarke & Co.|isbn=978-0-227-67978-4|page=122}} [[Franz Wokenius]] wrote a 1728 Latin work on Whiston's view of primitive Christianity.{{cite book |last=Wokenius |first=Franz |title=Christianismus primaevus quem Guil. Whistonus modo non-probando restituendum dictitat sed Apostolus Paulus breviter quasi in tabula depinxit ...|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pVfitgAACAAJ|accessdate=25 May 2013|year=1728}} His challenge to the teachings of [[Athanasius]] meant that Whiston was commonly considered [[heresy|heretical]] on many points. On the other hand, he was a firm believer in supernatural aspects of Christianity. He defended prophecy and miracle. He supported [[anoint]]ing the sick and touching for the [[king's evil]]. His dislike of [[rationalism]] in religion also made him one of the numerous opponents of Hoadley's ''Plain Account of the Nature and End of the Sacrament''. He was fervent in his views of ecclesiastical government and discipline, derived from the ''Apostolical Constitutions''. About 1747 Whiston finally left the [[Anglican communion]] for the [[Baptists]]. He quitted the church literally as well as figuratively, as the clergyman began to read the [[Athanasian Creed]]. ==Lecturer and popular author== Whiston began lecturing on natural philosophy in London. He gave regular courses at [[coffee house#coffee in Europe|coffee house]]s, particularly Button's, and also at the Censorium, a set of riverside meeting rooms in London run by [[Richard Steele]].{{cite book|author1=Margaret C. Jacob|author2=Larry Stewart|title=Practical Matter: Newton's Science in the Service of Industry and Empire 1687–1851|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yU8zZrK2JPgC&pg=PA64|accessdate=21 May 2013|date=30 June 2009|publisher=Harvard University Press|isbn=978-0-674-03903-2|page=64}} At Button's, he gave courses of demonstration lectures on astronomical and physical phenomena, and [[Francis Hauksbee the younger]] worked with him on experimental demonstrations. His passing remarks on religious topics were sometimes objected to, for example by [[Henry Newman (SPCK)|Henry Newman]] writing to Steele.{{MacTutor|title=London Coffee houses and mathematics|id=Coffee_houses|class=HistTopics}}{{cite ODNB|id=12619|title=Hauksbee, Francis|first=Larry|last=Stewart}} [[File:Whiston Senex solar system chart.jpg|thumb|left|Solar system chart by William Whiston and John Senex]] His lectures were often accompanied by publications. In 1712, he published, with [[John Senex]], a chart of the [[solar system]] showing numerous paths of comets.{{cite book|editor1=Thomas Hockey|editor2=Katherine Bracher|editor3=Marvin Bolt|editor4=Virginia Trimble|editor5= Richard Jarrell|editor6= JoAnn Palmeri|editor7= Jordan D. Marché|editor8= Thomas Williams|editor9= F. Jamil Ragep|title=Biographical Encyclopedia of Astronomers|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=t-BF1CHkc50C&pg=PA1213|accessdate=25 May 2013|date=18 September 2007|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-0-387-30400-7|pages=1213}} In 1715, he lectured on the total [[solar eclipse of May 3, 1715|solar eclipse of 3 May 1715]] (which fell in April [[Old Style]] in England); Whiston lectured on it at the time, in [[Covent Garden]], and later, as a natural event and as a portent.{{cite book |last=Knox |first=Kevin C. |title=From Newton to Hawking: A History of Cambridge University's Lucasian Professors of Mathematics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QGX_rAeia4kC&pg=PA162|accessdate=22 May 2013|date=6 November 2003|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-66310-6|page=162}} By 1715 Whiston had also become adept at newspaper advertising.{{cite book |last=Wigelsworth |first=Jeffrey R. |title=Selling Science in the Age of Newton: Advertising and the Commoditization of Knowledge|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Yi2S_ZiFxaQC&pg=PA137|accessdate=25 May 2013|year=2010|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.|isbn=978-1-4094-2310-2|page=137}} He frequently lectured to the Royal Society. ==Longitude== In 1714, he was instrumental in the passing of the [[Longitude Act]], which established the [[Board of Longitude]]. In collaboration with [[Humphrey Ditton]] he published ''A New Method for Discovering the Longitude, both at Sea and Land'',{{cite book |last=Ditton |first=William Whiston |last2=Ditton |first2=Humphrey |title=A New Method for Discovering the Longitude, both at Sea and Land|url=http://writersinspire.podcasts.ox.ac.uk/content/new-method-discovering-longitude-both-sea-land-humbly-proposed-consideration-publick-william|accessdate=15 Apr 2015|year=1714|publisher=John Phillips}} which was widely referenced and discussed. For the next forty years he continued to propose a range of methods to solve the [[Longitude prize|longitude reward]], which earned him widespread ridicule, particularly from the group of writers known as the [[Scriblerians]].For example, [[Jonathan Swift]]'s 1714 "Ode, to Musick. On the Longitude," including numerous references to bepissing and beshitting upon both Whiston and Ditton.S.D. Snobelen, ‘William Whiston: Natural Philosopher, Prophet, Primitive Christian’ (Cambridge Univ. Ph.D. Thesis, 2000) In one proposal for using magnetic dip to find longitude he produced one of the first [[Isoclinic line|isoclinic]] maps of southern England in 1719 and 1721. In 1734, he proposed using the [[eclipse]]s of [[Moons of Jupiter|Jupiter's satellites]].[http://cudl.lib.cam.ac.uk/view/MS-MSS-00079-00130-00002/1 Mr Whiston's Project for finding the Longitude (MSS/79/130.2)], Board of Longitude project, [[University of Cambridge]] Digital Library ==Broader natural philosophy== Whiston's ''[[A New Theory of the Earth|A New Theory of the Earth from its Original to the Consummation of All Things]]'' (1696) was an articulation of [[creationism]] and [[flood geology]]. It held that the [[deluge (mythology)|global flood]] of [[Noah]] had been caused by a [[comet]]. The work obtained the praise of [[John Locke]], who classed the author among those who, if not adding much to our knowledge, "At least bring some new things to our thoughts." He was an early advocate, along with [[Edmond Halley]], of the periodicity of comets; he also held that comets were responsible for past [[catastrophism|catastrophes]] in Earth's history. In 1736, he caused widespread anxiety among London's citizens when he predicted the world would end on [[October 16|16 October]] that year because a comet would hit the earth.{{Cite web|url=https://www.aps.org/publications/apsnews/201511/physicshistory.cfm|title=This Month in Physics History|language=en|access-date=2018-10-16}} [[William Wake]] as [[Archbishop of Canterbury]] officially denied this prediction to calm the public. There was no consensus within the Newtonians as to how far mechanical causes could be held responsible for key events of sacred history: [[John Keill]] was at the opposite to extreme to Whiston in minimising such causes.{{cite book |last=Poole |first=William |title=The World Makers: Scientists of the Restoration and the Search for the Origins of the Earth|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=--Z4LNo40cwC&pg=PA72|accessdate=25 May 2013|year=2010|publisher=Peter Lang|isbn=978-1-906165-08-6|page=72}} As a natural philosopher, Whiston's speculations respected no boundary with his theological views. He saw the creation of man as an intervention in the [[Natural order (philosophy)|natural order]]. He picked up on [[Arthur Ashley Sykes]]'s advice to Samuel Clarke to omit an eclipse and earthquake mentioned by [[Phlegon of Tralles]] from future editions of Clarke's Boyle lectures, these events being possibly synchronous with [[Christ's crucifixion]]. Whiston published ''The Testimony of Phlegon Vindicated'' in 1732.{{cite book |last=Force |first=James E. |title=William Whiston: Honest Newtonian|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=np9s8TGaSnYC&pg=PA181|accessdate=25 May 2013|date=29 March 1985|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-26590-4|page=181 note 128}} ==Views== The series of [[Moyer Lectures]] often made Whiston's unorthodox views a particular target.{{cite book|author1=J.E. Force|author2=S. Hutton|title=Newton and Newtonianism: New Studies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oKT9HfHQ5tEC&pg=PA102|accessdate=25 May 2013|year=2004|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-1-4020-1969-2|page=102}} Whiston held that ''[[Song of Solomon]]'' was [[apocrypha]]l and that the ''[[Book of Baruch]]'' was not. He modified the biblical [[Ussher chronology]], setting the [[Genesis creation narrative|Creation]] at 4010 BCE.{{cite book|author1=Davis A. Young|author2=Ralph Stearley|title=The Bible, Rocks and Time: Geological Evidence for the Age of the Earth|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TRKtFWlSrRsC&pg=PA67|accessdate=23 May 2013|date=18 August 2008|publisher=InterVarsity Press|isbn=978-0-8308-2876-0|page=67}} He challenged Newton's system of ''[[The Chronology of Ancient Kingdoms Amended]]'' (1728). Westfall absolves Whiston of the charge that he pushed for the posthumous publication of the ''Chronology'' just to attack it, commenting that the heirs were in any case looking to publish manuscripts of Newton, who died in 1727.{{cite book|last=Westfall |first=Richard S. |authorlink=Richard S. Westfall|title=Never at Rest: A Biography of Isaac Newton|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3ngEugMMa9YC&pg=PA815|accessdate=25 May 2013|date=29 April 1983|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-27435-7|pages=815 note 112}} Whiston's advocacy of clerical [[monogamy]] is referenced in ''[[The Vicar of Wakefield]]''. His last "famous discovery, or rather revival of Dr [[Giles Fletcher, the Elder]]'s," which he mentions in his autobiography, was the identification of the [[Tatars]] with the [[lost tribes of Israel]]. ==Personal life== Whiston married Ruth, daughter of George Antrobus, his headmaster at Tamworth school. He had a happy family life and died in [[Lyndon, Rutland|Lyndon]] Hall, [[Rutland]], at the home of his son-in-law, [[Samuel Barker (Hebraist)|Samuel Barker]], on 22 August 1752. He was survived by his children Sarah, William, George, and John.{{cn|date=December 2017}} ==Works== Whiston's later life was spent in continual controversy: [[theology|theological]], mathematical, [[chronology|chronological]], and miscellaneous. He vindicated his estimate of the ''Apostolical Constitutions'' and the Arian views he had derived from them in his ''Primitive Christianity Revived'' (5 vols., 1711–1712). In 1713 he produced a reformed [[liturgy]]. His ''Life of Samuel Clarke'' appeared in 1730. His translation of the works of [[Josephus]] (1737), with notes and dissertations, was often reprinted. In 1745 he published his ''Primitive New Testament'' (on the basis of [[Codex Bezae]] and [[Codex Claromontanus]]). Whiston left memoirs (3 vols., 1749–1750). These do not contain the account of the proceedings taken against him at Cambridge for his [[antitrinitarianism]], which was published separately at the time. ==See also== * [[Noah's Flood]] * [[Catastrophism]] * [[Biblical prophecy]] * [[Dorsa Whiston]], named after him ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==Further reading== *{{cite book | first = Maureen | last = Farrell | year = 1981 | title = William Whiston | publisher = Arno Press | location = New York}} *{{cite book | first = James E. | last = Force | year = 2002 | title = William Whiston: Honest Newtonian | publisher = Cambridge University Press | location = Cambridge}} * {{cite book | first=W.
